author: JEFF FLETCHER
title: ANGELS: Playoff hopes fade with 5-3 loss to Rangers
text:
BY JEFF FLETCHER / STAFF WRITER
Published: Oct. 1, 2015 Updated: 11:07 p.m. ARLINGTON, Texas – The Angels fought for weeks to get close enough to see the playoff finish line with control of their destiny, and now it’s gone.
After a 5-3 loss to the Texas Rangers on Thursday night, the Angels' playoff chances have slipped to the point where they need some help.
The Angels were eliminated from the American League West race, and now they are a full game behind the Houston Astros in the wild-card race, with just three games to go. The Angels are also tied with the Minnesota Twins.
That means the Angels not only need to win, but they need the Astros to lose at least once over the weekend against the Arizona Diamondbacks.
If the Angels and Astros tie after Sunday’s games, they would play a tiebreaker game in Houston. If all three teams tie, the Twins and Astros would play and the winner would host the Angels.
Now, instead of simply win-and-you’re-in, the Angels need help, thanks to two straight losses after their seven-game winning streak.
After losing Wednesday because of a season-high four errors, Thursday's game fell apart in one frustrating inning.
The Angels had a 1-0 in the middle of the fifth, with Andrew Heaney having worked his way around three walks and two hits in the first four innings.
In the fifth, Heaney gave up a leadoff single to Elvis Andrus. After a popout, he walked Robinson Chirinos. Delino DeShields then lined a double into center field, driving in one run.
Heaney then threw a 2-2 pitch that appeared to be on the inside corner to Shin-Soo Choo, but he didn’t get the call. He then walked Choo on the next pitch.
Adrian Beltre then yanked a 2-2 slider that wasn’t even a strike into left field for a three-run double, putting the Rangers up 4-1.
The situation certainly opened Manager Mike Scioscia up to second-guessing about why he didn’t pull Heaney, who had thrown 79 pitches after the walk to Choo.
The problem was that two of the next three hitters were left-handed, so if Scioscia would have brought in a righty to face the right-handed Beltre, it would have likely been for just one batter. That would have begun a flood of relievers in the fifth inning.
As it turned out, he started anyway, because he pulled Heaney after the Beltre double, bringing in another lefty, Jose Alvarez, for just three batters.
The Angels got back into the game on Albert Pujols’ 39 th homer in the sixth, and a two-out RBI single from Erick Aybar in the seventh. Kole Calhoun then hit a chopper into the hole on the left side, but shortstop Elvis Andrus made a nice play and a strong throw to get the third out.
Adding some salt to the Angels' wounds, Josh Hamilton had a big hand in their defeat.
In the second inning, he made a sprawing catch at the fence to rob Shane Victorino of an extra-base hit. He also doubled and hit a sacrifice fly to add an insurance run in the seventh.
